title: PCBs and chlorinated pesticides in adult male Polar Bears (Ursus maritimus) from Alaska
name: pcbs-and-chlorinated-pesticides-in-adult-male-polar-bears-ursus-maritimus-from-alaska
notes: Persistent organochlorines (OC) contaminants, including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB) congeners, Dichlorophenyltrichloroethane (DDT) and its metabolites including DDE, chlordane-related compounds (CHL), hexachlorocylohexane isomers(HCH), and the chlorinated pesticides dieldrin, endrin, mirex, and toxaphene were measured in adipose tissue of adult male polar bears from the Southern Beaufort Sea and the Chukchi/Bering Seas populations in Alaska. The geometric mean concentration (u00b1 SD), on a lipid weight basis (lw), of u00d3PCBs (sum of 18 congeners) for polar bears from the Southern Beaufort Sea and the Chukchi/Bering Seas was 2.49 u00b1 1.41 ug/g lw and 1.54 u00b1 1.69 ug/g lw, respectively. Six congeners PCB-99, PCB-153, PCB-138, PCB-180, PCB-170, and PCB-194 accounted for 92% of the u00d3PCB. The geometric mean for u00d3CHL, u00d3HCH, and u00d3DDT concentrations for the Southern Beaufort Sea and Chukchi/Bering Seas populations were 0.76 u00b1 1.95 ug/g lw vs. 0.47 u00b1 1.77ug/g lw, 1.01 u00b1 1.91 ug/g lw vs. 0.84 u00b1 1.78 ug/g lw, and 0.054 u00b1 2.12 ug/g lw vs. 0.062 u00b1 2.24 ug/g lw, respectively. Concentrations of u00d3PCB and u00d3CHL were significantly greater in the Southern Beaufort Sea than in the Chukchi/Bering Seas. The percentage of oxychlordane in the u00d3CHL (69%) and t-nonachlor (16%), the principle components of u00d3CHL, were similar for both populations. Except for u00d3HCH, the sum of major polychlorinated biphenyl congeners (u00d3PCB), u00d3CHL and u00d3DDT concentrations were relatively low compared to other Arctic polar bear populations. u00c2-HCH, the most persistent isomer of u00d3HCH, accounted for 93.6% of the u00d3HCH. u00d3HCH increased with age and u00d3CHL decreased with age. Adult male polar bears may not be reliable indicators of concentrations of DDE, dieldrin, and u00d3CHL in the Arctic ecosystem. The overall low concentrations and patterns of the PCB congeners and chlorinated pesticides from the Alaskan populations suggest that either contaminant levels in ringed seals are low or that polar bears may feed more frequently on prey from lower trophic levels, such as bowhead whales, Pacific walrus, and bearded seals, than polar bears from other Arctic populations. The patterns and concentrations of OCs indicate that there may be a greater influence of contaminant sources from Southeast Asia, western North America, and the North Pacific Ocean than for other polar bear populations which are more influenced by contaminant sources from North America (eastern Canada western Greenland) the European Arctic (eastern Greenland, Svalbard, Norway, and Russia).

organization.title: US Fish and Wildlife Service, Department of the Interior
organization.name: fws-gov
